choices.text: The magistrate is the authorising officer in case of exhumation
In India, medico-legal autopsies are typically performed by trained forensic doctors

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding medico-legal autopsy?
questions.solution:
Explanation of the answer:

In medico-legal autopsies, consent from relatives is not required, as they are conducted under legal authority for investigative purposes.

Preliminaries/Formalities of a Forensic Autopsy:

  • Consent Not Required:
    • Informed consent from legal heirs is not necessary for a forensic autopsy.
    • Legal heirs are usually informed as a formality.
  • Body Handling:
    • The body was handed over to the autopsy surgeon by the legal authority.
    • After the autopsy, the body was returned to legal authority.
    • Legal authority formally hands over the body to the legal heirs for the last rites. (Option B)
    • The chain of custody must be documented at all stages.
  • Presence Restrictions:
    • No casual observers are allowed.
    • Maintain a register of legally authorised persons present during autopsy.
  • Ideal Location:
    • Well-equipped, ventilated, illuminated autopsy room near the mortuary is preferred.
    • Autopsies may also be conducted at:
      • Site of discovery (e.g., decomposed body)
      • Exhumation site
      • Temporary arrangements at disaster sites (e.g., mass disasters)
    • In cases of exhumation, the Magistrate is the authorising officer. (Option C)
  • Qualified Personnel: (Option D)
    • Ideally performed by trained forensic doctors.
    • In rural/remote areas of developing countries, general doctors may conduct autopsies if forensic experts are unavailable.

Reference: 

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK539901/

questions.text: In which of the following scenarios is an autopsy not typically performed at the site of body recovery?
questions.solution:
Explanation of the answer:

Autopsies for road traffic accident (RTA) deaths are typically conducted in an equipped mortuary to ensure proper facilities for detailed examination, imaging, and sample collection.

Ideal Location for Forensic Autopsy:

  • The best location is a well-equipped, well-ventilated, well-illuminated autopsy room adjacent to the mortuary.
  • Forensic autopsies may also be conducted at:
    • The scene of the discovery of a decomposed body.
    • The site of exhumation of a dead body.
    • Temporary arrangements are set up at the site of mass disasters, depending on the circumstances.

Reference: 

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK539901/#

questions.text: Which autopsy incision is most appropriate in a case of asphyxial death due to neck compression?
questions.solution:
Explanation of the answer:

Y-shaped incision is preferred in asphyxial deaths (e.g., hanging, strangulation) due to better access to neck structures.

Skin Incisions in Forensic Autopsy:

  1. "I"-Shaped Incision: (Option A)
    • Extends from the chin to the symphysis pubis, passing either to the left or right of the umbilicus.
    • The umbilicus is avoided due to the presence of dense fibrous tissue, which is difficult to suture after autopsy.
    • The most common skin incision used to open the thoracic and abdominal cavities.
  2. "Y"-Shaped Incision: (Option B)
    • Begins near the acromial process (shoulder region).
    • Extends down below the breast and across to the xiphoid process.
    • A similar incision is made on the opposite side.
    • From the xiphoid process, the incision continues down to the symphysis pubis.
    • Indicated in suspected strangulation, hanging, or cases with potential laryngeal damage, as it allows wide access to neck structures.
  3. Modified "Y"-Shaped Incision: (Option C)
    • A midline incision from the suprasternal notch to the symphysis pubis.
    • From the suprasternal notch, the incision extends over the clavicle to its centre on both sides.
    • It then passes upwards over the neck behind the ear.
    • Provides wide exposure of the neck and thoracic structures.
  4. X-Shaped Incision: (Option D)
    • Skin is reflected by an X-shaped incision over the back and limbs.
    • Useful to detect and evaluate hidden subcutaneous haemorrhages, particularly in cases of custodial deaths.

References: 

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK539901/#

questions.text: Which autopsy technique involves the 'en masse' removal of all organs as a single block?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In Letulle's technique, all cervical, thoracic, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed together as a single block (en masse) and dissected afterwards.

questions.text:
In which scenarios is a second autopsy typically performed?
1. The relatives are not satisfied with the first autopsy report
2. The first autopsy was not performed in the light of the circumstances which are now available
3. The investigating authority demands a second autopsy
4. The first autopsy was done in the absence of the investigating officer
5. The first autopsy was done in the absence of relatives
questions.solution:
Explanation of correct answer:

The correct statements are 1, 2, and 3.

Second Autopsy:

  • A second autopsy is performed after the first autopsy on the same body.
  • Indications for Second Autopsy:
    • Requested by relatives dissatisfied with the first autopsy findings. (Statement 1)
    • Requested by investigating agencies when: (Statement 3)
      • Some questions remain unanswered.
      • Issues are left unattended in the first autopsy.
    • Suspected involvement of:
      • The first autopsy doctor was concealing facts.
      • The first autopsy was performed without considering certain facts or circumstances that have come to light later. (Statement 2)
      • Police authorities hide evidence; the body is then shifted out of their jurisdiction before a second autopsy.
  • Minimum Requirements for Conduct of Second Autopsy:
    • A proper requisition letter should be provided.
    • First autopsy report and all relevant case records should be made available.
    • Second autopsy should not be conducted at the same centre as the first autopsy.
    • Preferably conducted at another centre by a Professor of Forensic Medicine from a Government Medical College.
    • Ideally, a panel of doctors should be formed, which may include:
      • A Surgeon
      • A Gynaecologist
      • A Pathologist, etc., depending on the case specifics.

Reference: 

https://www.researchgate.net/publication/279203058_Second_Autopsy_The_Indian_Scenario

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK539901/#

questions.text: Which metal can be detected in the charred bones and ashes of conflagrated human remains?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Arsenic can be detected even in the conflagration of human bones.

Detection of Arsenic in Burnt Bones and Ashes:

  • Arsenic detection after cremation is scientifically expected in genuine arsenic poisoning due to the following reasons:
  1. Conversion to Arsenates:
    • Much of the arsenic in bones converts to arsenates, which partially replace phosphates in bones.
    • Arsenates are non-volatile, so arsenic remains detectable even after prolonged strong heating.
  2. Incomplete Combustion during Cremation:
    • In India, cremation conditions often do not favour complete combustion.
    • Even if arsenic is present as arsenic trioxide or another volatile form, not all arsenic is lost.
    • Some volatilized arsenic may condense on cooler parts of the funeral pyre, preventing its complete loss.
  3. Site of Detection:
    • Arsenic is especially detectable in the spongy bones, such as:
      • Skull
      • Vertebrae
    • Arsenic can persist here long after its disappearance from soft organs like the liver, spleen, kidneys, or brain.

Explanation of other options:

Thallium (Option A): Highly volatile; unlikely to be detected after intense burning.

Mercury (Option B): Extremely volatile; vaporises at low temperatures, is lost during cremation.

Cadmium (Option D): Also volatile; vaporises during high-temperature exposure like cremation.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5184956/pdf/indmedgaz72575-0019.pdf

questions.text: While doing an autopsy on a victim of strangulation, you are examining his brain. Which of the following areas of the brain is the most likely to show evidence of hypoxic damage in this victim?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The hippocampus, particularly the CA1 region, is among the most sensitive areas of the brain to hypoxic-ischemic damage.

Parts of the Brain Most Suitable for Detecting Hypoxic Damage:

  • Hippocampus: Especially the CA1 sector (Sommer's area) and subiculum.
  • Cerebellar Folia
  • Globus Pallidus, part of the basal ganglia.
  • Boundary Zones (Watershed Areas) of the Cerebral Cortex:
    • Particularly, the parasagittal region of the middle frontal gyrus, where the watershed between the middle and anterior cerebral arteries lies.
    • These areas are vulnerable due to being at the terminal reaches of the arterial supply.
  • Cortical Layers Most Suitable for Histological Detection: The third and fourth cortical layers show the clearest histological changes of hypoxia.

Reference: 

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK537310/
